author: alx9r
body:
I'm trying to understand why the following two statements yield different outputs:

```PowerShell
&{,$null} | % {'x'} # x
&{,(1)[1]} | % {'x'} # no output
```

`,$null` and `,(1)[1]` both seem to be arrays containing a single null element.  Yet they behave differently during output from a scriptblock.  What is happening here?

comments.author: powercode
comments.body:
The second returns `AutomationNull.Value` which is not enumerated by the pipeline.

`$null` is enumerated.

See for example the implementation of foreach:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/bcf86d4f8a1ce0ef11f0e9100490e790fb067574/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/runtime/Operations/MiscOps.cs#L2748

comments.author: alx9r
comments.body:
Thank you @powercode.  For other readers, here are some resources on `AutomationNull`:

* [#5674 (comment)](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5674#issuecomment-352260793)
* [stackoverflow.com: Why and how are these two $null values different?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30016949)

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body: @alx9r: This comes down to the question you later asked in #6436 and which I've brought into focus in https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6436#issuecomment-375151317, but I've decided to create a separate issue for it: #6823

title: Why is ,(1)[1] different from ,$null?
